T  echnical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 46512  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
October 2013 
 
 
 
Independent State of Samoa: Promoting Economic 
Use of Customary Land, Phase III
  
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 1 October 2013) 
 
Currency unit –  tala (ST) 
ST1.00 =  $0.4351 
$1.00 =  ST2.298 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CLAC  –  Customary Land Advisory Commission 
  LWG  –  legal working group 
TA  –  technical assistance 
   
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION

Targeting  –  General intervention  
classification 
Sector (subsector)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling

reforms), capacity development (institutional development)

NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars unless otherwise stated. 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  X. Yao, Pacific Department (PARD) 
Regional Director  A. Ruthenberg, Pacific Subregional Office, PARD 
   
Team leader  M. Lototele, Senior Economics Officer, PARD 
Team member  C. Currie, Senior Country Economist, PARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
 
II.  ISSUES  1 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  3 
A.  Impact and Outcome  3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  4 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  4 
 
APPENDIXES  
1.  Design and Monitoring Framework  5 
2.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  6 
3.  Outline Terms of Reference for Consultants  7

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Samoa has requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical 
assistance (TA) to support its efforts to promote the economic use of customary land. The 
government’s commitment to promoting the economic use of customary land is expressed in 
key outcome 5 of the Samoa Development Strategy, 2012–2016,1 which focuses on improving 
the enabling environment for business development. One of the strategic areas identified under 
this outcome is raising the efficiency and effectiveness of the public service to support the 
private sector and the community. The proposed TA has been included in the TA program for 
2013  of  the  ADB  country  operations  business  plan,  2014–2016.2 The  country  operations 
business plan supports the Samoa Development Strategy by targeting improved delivery of 
public services, including the removal of constraints to infrastructure investment, and promotion 
of private sector development, which directly links to key outcome 5 of the Samoa Development 
Strategy. 
 
2.  An ADB fact-finding mission was conducted between 23–26 July 2013 to reach an 
understanding with the government on the objectives and scope of the TA, cost estimates, 
financing plan, implementation arrangements, and detailed terms of reference for consulting 
services. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  More than 80% of all businesses in Samoa have five employees or less. These micro 
and small enterprises generally lack equity and access to bank lending to provide a sustainable 
financing base for their enterprise. With at least 80% of land under customary communal 
ownership that cannot be alienated either by sale or mortgage, most enterprises have limited 
choices  of  acceptable  securities  that  they  can  offer  to  access  financial  services.  While 
customary land is available, micro and small enterprises cannot use such land as collateral 
because (i) property rights (until recently) could not be mortgaged, (ii) the status of leases as 
collateral is legally certain but is often discouraged by lending institutions, (iii) security of tenure 
may not be guaranteed even when leasehold title is obtained, and (iv) the lease approval 
process is cumbersome  and  can take  up  to 12  months.  The  limited  freehold  land  that  is 
available for securing loans from commercial banks is concentrated around the Apia urban area. 
Therefore, the problem of access to financial services is compounded for rural businesses in 
Upolu and Savai’i. Enforceability problems and the state of the relevant registries discourages 
commercial banks from using chattels as acceptable securities. 
 
4.  There is also high demand for customary lands from foreign investors. However, the 
landowners need to organize themselves to take advantage of this. The Alienation of Customary 
Land Act, 1965 recognizes that the matai (family chief) can, on behalf of the family, offer to 
lease the family’s customary land should there be an interested investor. However, while the 
land is registered in the name of the matai, the legal system recognizes all members of the 
group as owners. Any dealing with foreign investors therefore requires that all members of the 
landowning group are identified and have their names recorded on any land dealing, and all 
members of the landowning group (including absentee owners) must consent to any dealing. 
These requirements prolong the approval process and discourage long-term land development. 
                                                 
1  Government of Samoa. 2012. Samoa Development Strategy (2012–2016). Apia. 
2  ADB. 2013. Country Operations Business Plan: Samoa, 2014–2016. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 2 October 2013.

2 
 
5.  ADB’s involvement in promoting the economic use of customary land in Samoa began 
with exploratory work under component 4 of the Small Business Development Project and the 
associated TA for Capacity Building of Financial and Business Development Intermediaries, 
which aimed to improve the policy and legislative environment for small business development. 4 
The Small Business Development Project explored ways to improve the access of micro and 
small enterprises to credit, including through establishing leasehold on customary land. Under 
the subsequent TA for Promoting Economic Use of Customary Land, a program implementation 
plan  was  prepared  that  recommended  (i)  establishment  of  a  customary  land  advisory 
commission (CLAC), (ii) setting up of a one-stop shop for customary land matters, and (iii) 
extensive use of community advocacy. 5 
 
6.  ADB provided further technical assistance to assist the government in (i) establishing the 
CLAC through the CLAC Act, 2013; (ii) setting up the Customary Land Leasing Section; and (iii) 
amending the Alienation of Customary Land Act, 1965 to allow the mortgage of customary land 
leases. 6 CLAC was formed to (i) advise the Cabinet on the facilitation, encouragement, and 
promotion  of  economic  use  of  customary  land;  (ii)  conduct  public  consultations  on  areas 
affecting customary land considered to be in need of reform; and (iii) review all laws affecting 
customary land in Samoa and make recommendations to the Cabinet for changes to such laws. 
The Customary Land Leasing Section, which is housed within the Ministry of Natural Resources 
and Environment, now acts as the one-stop shop where landowners and investors can get 
information and advice on customary land.  
 
7.  To support this initiative, the government set up an office and provided office equipment 
for  CLAC,  established  an  independent  secretariat  (separate  from  the  existing  government 
structure) to support CLAC, and provided resources in the national budget to support the 
operation  of  CLAC  for  7  years  (commissions  would  normally  operate  for  2  years).  The 
government has also ensured that a legal framework is in place to promote the economic use of 
customary land. While the use of customary land as mortgage is prohibited under Article 102 of 
the Constitution of Samoa, the mortgage of customary leasehold interest is now possible. 
 
8.  To support the mortgaging of customary leasehold, there is a need to put in place a 
lease framework. The lease framework will allow for (i) creating a security interest in leases, (ii) 
establishing priority for the lender, (iii) publicizing security interests in leases so that interested 
parties can establish if a lease has already been pledged as security, and (iv) creating a 
process for repossessing and selling the lease in the event of default. The lease framework 
must be consistent with Samoa’s seven principles of dealing with customary land (para. 9), but 
must allow for ready sale of leases if the borrower defaults.  
 
9.  In discussing the economic use of customary land, the TA will ensure that it operates 
within Samoa’s seven principles (enshrined in written laws and Samoa’s culture) of dealing with 
customary land:  
                                                 
4  ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
Independent State of Samoa for Small Business Development Project. Manila (Loan 1785-SAM, approved on 21 
November): ADB. 2000. Technical Assistance to the Independent State of Samoa for Capacity Building of Financial 
and Business Intermediaries. Manila (TA 3549-SAM, approved on 21 November). The project completion report 
rated the project partly successful.  
5  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the Independent State of Samoa for Promoting Economic Use of Customary 
Land. Manila (TA 4712-SAM, approved in December). 
6  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the Independent State of Samoa for Promoting Economic Use of Customary 
Land, Phase II. Manila (TA 7387-SAM, approved in November).

3 
 
(i)  customary land will not be alienable or alienated and cannot be sold,  
(ii)  primary decision making on use of customary land stays with the matai and 
family,   
(iii)  the lease application process should be as efficient and practicable as possible,  
(iv)  the process should produce robust and bankable leases,   
(v)  the government will improve the transparency of its processes and the capacity 
of its departments and institutions,  
(vi)  the government will promote and facilitate the efficient use of land for economic 
development of Samoa, and   
(vii)  disputes will be resolved in an efficient and timely manner and according to law. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of the TA will be improved access to credit for business investment. This will 
be measured by credit to the private sector increasing from 43% of gross domestic product in 
2012 to 50% in 2019 based on annual figures of the Central Bank of Samoa. The outcome will 
be  the  use  of  customary  land  leases  as  collateral.  The  achievement  will  be  reflected  in 
commercial banks accepting customary land leases as collateral.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  Section 15 of the CLAC Act allows the mortgage of customary land leases. However, 
despite their willingness to move into this area, commercial banks are yet to take advantage of 
this because of different legal interpretations of Section 102 of the Constitution of Samoa; 
Section 4 of the Alienation of Customary Land Act, 1965; and Section 15 of the CLAC Act, 2013. 
This is despite an independent legal opinion (sought by the Office of the Attorney General) that 
the  mortgage  of  customary  land  leases  is  now  possible.  To  discuss  and  resolve  these 
differences, the TA is expected to provide the following outputs. 
 
12.  Output  1:  A  functional  legal  working  group  established.  Given  that  the  legal 
framework is in place to allow the mortgage of customary land leases, CLAC will establish a 
legal working group (LWG) to work closely with the Banking Association of Samoa to discuss 
further actions required to enable commercial banks to take advantage of this legal framework 
and accept customary land leases as collateral. As a test case, an overseas investor has 
approached ANZ Bank (Samoa branch) to borrow money using as collateral the customary land 
lease they obtained from one of the villages. CLAC and the LWG will work closely with the ANZ 
Bank,  the  overseas  investor,  and  the  government  to  broker  this  deal  and  establish  the 
precedent. 
 
13.  Output 2: Leasing framework established. The TA will assist CLAC to establish a 
leasing framework for the use of customary leasehold as collateral. In establishing the leasing 
framework, the TA will ensure that the framework addresses four issues: (i) the process for the 
registration of a security interest, (ii) perfection of the security interest, (iii) the publicizing of 
security interests in leases, and (iv) the process for repossessing and reselling the lease in the 
event of default.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $480,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office accommodation, and office supplies. The 
government has also allocated sufficient resources in its 2014 budget to support the operation 
of CLAC and has committed to continue to support CLAC for the next 7 years. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency for the TA and will ensure that TA 
activities are closely coordinated with the implementing agencies (Ministry of Natural Resources 
and Environment, and Ministry of Justice and Courts Administration). CLAC will act as the 
conduit to the Cabinet when decisions require higher endorsement. CLAC will be supported by 
its secretariat as well as the LWG. Given the sensitivity of issues around customary land, 
consultations with civil society and nongovernment organizations will be done regularly.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over a 3-year period from January 2014 to December 2016. 
The 3 year timeframe is based on the need to ensure that the government have enough time to 
consult the stakeholders given the sensitivity of land reform in Samoa. The TA is expected to 
finance 8 person-months of intermittent international consulting services and 14 person-months 
of national consulting services. The consultant team will have a team leader and program 
coordinator (national, 10 person-months), a legal specialist (international, 8 person-months), 
and a legal adviser (national, 4 person-months). The international consultant will be a senior 
technical specialist in his or her field with extensive experience in small-island states. The 
consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis according to ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 3. Proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
17.  The team leader will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones for the duration of the TA, and a final report summarizing the achievements, issues, 
lessons learned, and next steps. The TA will also prepare knowledge products (policy briefs, 
detailed project description on the process, and implementation of customary land reform in 
Samoa) given the interest on land reform in the rest of the Pacific Island Countries. Throughout 
the TA, the team leader will submit (by email) brief monthly progress reports summarizing TA 
activities, progress, issues, and constraints. The final report will be submitted in draft form at 
least 5 weeks prior to the end of the assignment, and the final report within 2 weeks of receipt 
of comments from the government and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Samoa for Promoting Economic Use of Customary Land, Phase III, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

Appendix 3  7 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Program Coordinator and Team Leader (national, 10 person-months)  
 
1.  The program coordinator will have at least 10 years of experience in the public or private 
sectors, including demonstrated experience in managing reform processes. The consultant will 
have a sound knowledge of traditional Samoan land tenure arrangements, requirements for a 
conducive  business  environment,  and  government  processes.  He  or  she  will  have  a 
demonstrated capacity to coordinate and communicate effectively with diverse groups and 
interests. Effective oral and written communication skills in both Samoan and English languages 
will  be  essential,  with  media  skills  an  advantage.  Project  management,  monitoring,  and 
reporting skills will also be a distinct advantage. Demonstrated ability to supervise consultants is 
essential. 
 
2.  The consultant will work closely with the nominated representative of the executing 
agency toward the achievement of project outputs and outcomes. Tasks will include monitoring, 
updating, and reporting on implementation of the technical assistance (TA). Reporting should 
focus on achievement of outputs and outcomes, measured in terms of indicators and targets set 
out in the action plans. The consultant will also actively support and work closely with the 
Customary Land Advisory Commission (CLAC) established by the government to manage the 
reform process, and the working groups sponsored by CLAC including leading consultations 
and discussions with civil society and nongovernment organizations. 
 
3.  The  program  coordinator  will  contribute  to  the  delivery  of  nontechnical  TA  outputs. 
These  will  include  drafting  administrative  instructions,  public  information  materials,  and 
education materials. The program coordinator will actively cooperate with his or her executing 
agency counterpart in promoting awareness of the relevant issues and reforms to the broader 
public.  The  consultant  will  support  capacity  development  among  staff  of  the  government 
agencies involved in customary land administration as appropriate, and will actively ensure that 
short-term consultants also pay attention to strengthening the technical capacity of relevant 
government agencies. 
 
4.  As  program  coordinator,  the  consultant  will  ensure  that  consultant  inputs  are  well 
coordinated and appropriately timed. He or she will ensure that all consultants have clear and 
appropriate  terms  of  reference  and  are  briefed  on  their  responsibilities,  progress  and 
outstanding  issues  for  the  reforms,  and  progress  of  the  TA.  The  program  coordinator  will 
compile reports from short-term consultants and quarterly progress reports, and draft project 
inception, draft, and final reports. The program coordinator will also prepare knowledge products 
(policy briefs, detailed project description on the process, and implementation of customary land 
reform in Samoa) for use outside of and in Samoa. 
 
B.  Legal Specialist (international, 8 person-months) 
 
5.    The legal specialist must have a tertiary qualification in law with a specialization in the 
creation  of  mortgage  finance  frameworks  for  land  leases,  preferably  in  countries  where 
communal landholdings exist. The specialist will have experience in establishing mortgage 
frameworks that involve land leases, and have expertise in property, banking, and mortgages. 
The specialist must be capable of rapidly familiarizing himself or herself with Samoa’s land 
tenure  system,  and  should  have  worked  internationally  on  similar  legal  frameworks  and 
communal land ownership. The legal specialist must provide a list of all experience and extent 
of involvement in the legislative drafting process and have a background in the practice of law in

8  Appendix 3 
Samoa, and must have a minimum of 5 years post-qualification experience. The specialist must 
have computer skills necessary for the efficient production of all required draft laws in electronic 
form, and be familiar with and comply with the Legislative Drafting Handbook issued by the 
Office of the Attorney General. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Review  all  existing  legislation  governing  the  potential  creation  of  security 
interests in land leases in Samoa. 
(ii)  Suggest any changes necessary to establish an effective system of using land 
leases as collateral. 
(iii)  Support  discussions  between  the  legal  working  group  and  the  Bankers 
Association  of  Samoa  on  options  for  how  customary  land  can  be  used  as 
collateral by commercial banks.  
(iv)  Support the work of CLAC and the legal working group in advising the Cabinet on 
the proposed way forward. 
(v)  If required, prepare drafting instructions for any new laws (and amendments to 
existing laws if required) in accordance with the requirements of the Legislative 
Drafting Handbook. 
(vi)  Undertake or oversee the drafting of any necessary changes to legislation.  
(vii)  Assist the program manager in preparing the TA reports. 
(viii)  Assist with any other task. 
 
C.  Legal Adviser (national, 4 person-months)  
 
6.  The legal specialist will have a tertiary qualification in law and be familiar with Samoa 
customary land law and recent changes that have occurred. He or she will be a member of the 
Samoa bar and be familiar with Samoa’s land tenure system. The legal specialist will work with 
the international legal specialist to develop a framework for the use of land leases as collateral 
for lending.
